The center of mass of a finite subset of a convex set belongs to the set
provided that all weights are non-negative, and the total weight is positive.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} {ι : Type u_5} [inst : LinearOrderedField R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : Module R E] {s : Set E} {t : Finset ι} {w : ι → R} {z : ι → E},
  Convex R s → (∀ i ∈ t, 0 ≤ w i) → (0 < Finset.sum t fun i => w i) → (∀ i ∈ t, z i ∈ s) → Finset.centerMass t w z ∈ s
name: Convex.centerMass_mem
docString:
The center of mass of a finite subset of a convex set belongs to the set
provided that all weights are non-negative, and the total weight is positive.

For all complex numbers x, Complex.exp x = Complex.cos x + Complex.i * Complex.sin x.

type: ∀ (x : ℂ), (x * Complex.I).exp = x.cos + x.sin * Complex.I
name: Complex.exp_mul_I
docString: For all complex numbers x, Complex.exp x = Complex.cos x + Complex.i * Complex.sin x.

This theorem states that the Schnirelmann density of a set of natural numbers is unaffected by the removal of the element `0`. In other words, for any set `A` of natural numbers, the Schnirelmann density of `A` and the Schnirelmann density of `A` without `0` are equal. The Schnirelmann density, defined as the infimum of the ratio of the cardinality of the intersection of `A` with the set `{1, ..., n}` to `n` as `n` ranges over the positive natural numbers, remains the same even if `0` is removed from set `A`. The predicates for membership in `A` and `A` without `0` are assumed to be decidable.

type:
∀ {A : Set ℕ} [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ∈ A] [inst_1 : DecidablePred fun x => x ∈ A \ {0}],
  schnirelmannDensity (A \ {0}) = schnirelmannDensity A
name: schnirelmannDensity_diff_singleton_zero
docString: This theorem states that the Schnirelmann density of a set of natural numbers is unaffected by the removal of the element `0`. In other words, for any set `A` of natural numbers, the Schnirelmann density of `A` and the Schnirelmann density of `A` without `0` are equal. The Schnirelmann density, defined as the infimum of the ratio of the cardinality of the intersection of `A` with the set `{1, ..., n}` to `n` as `n` ranges over the positive natural numbers, remains the same even if `0` is removed from set `A`. The predicates for membership in `A` and `A` without `0` are assumed to be decidable.

A map between two inner product spaces is a conformal map if and only if it preserves inner
products up to a scalar factor, i.e., there exists a positive `c : ℝ` such that
`⟪f u, f v⟫ = c * ⟪u, v⟫` for all `u`, `v`.

type:
∀ {E : Type u_1} {F : Type u_2} [inst : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup F]
  [inst_2 : InnerProductSpace ℝ E] [inst_3 : InnerProductSpace ℝ F] (f : E →L[ℝ] F),
  IsConformalMap f ↔ ∃ c, 0 < c ∧ ∀ (u v : E), ⟪f u, f v⟫_ℝ = c * ⟪u, v⟫_ℝ
name: isConformalMap_iff
docString:
A map between two inner product spaces is a conformal map if and only if it preserves inner
products up to a scalar factor, i.e., there exists a positive `c : ℝ` such that
`⟪f u, f v⟫ = c * ⟪u, v⟫` for all `u`, `v`.

A set of natural numbers has Schnirelmann density equal to 1 if and only if it contains all positive natural numbers.

type: ∀ {A : Set ℕ} [inst : DecidablePred fun x => x ∈ A], schnirelmannDensity A = 1 ↔ {0}ᶜ ⊆ A
name: schnirelmannDensity_eq_one_iff
docString: A set of natural numbers has Schnirelmann density equal to 1 if and only if it contains all positive natural numbers.

This theorem states that in a metric space equipped with the "Besicovitch property", any set `s` can be covered with a countable collection of closed balls in such a way that the sum of the measures (sizes) of these balls is at most the measure of the set `s` plus any positive real number `ε`. This is true even when we restrict the possible radii of the balls centered at a point `x` to be within a set `f x` that gets arbitrarily close to `0`. Specifically, for every point `x` in `s`, we can always find a radius within the intersection of `f x` and the open interval from `0` to any positive number `δ`, and we can then cover the set `s` with the closed balls centered at points in `t` (a subset of `s`) with these radii. The total measure of these balls will not exceed the measure of `s` plus `ε`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : MetricSpace α] [inst_1 : SecondCountableTopology α] [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace α]
  [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace α] [inst_4 : HasBesicovitchCovering α] (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α)
  [inst_5 : MeasureTheory.SigmaFinite μ] [inst_6 : μ.OuterRegular] {ε : ENNReal},
  ε ≠ 0 →
    ∀ (f : α → Set ℝ) (s : Set α),
      (∀ x ∈ s, ∀ δ > 0, (f x ∩ Set.Ioo 0 δ).Nonempty) →
        ∃ t r,
          t.Countable ∧
            t ⊆ s ∧
              (∀ x ∈ t, r x ∈ f x) ∧
                s ⊆ ⋃ x ∈ t, Metric.closedBall x (r x) ∧ ∑' (x : ↑t), ↑↑μ (Metric.closedBall (↑x) (r ↑x)) ≤ ↑↑μ s + ε
name: Besicovitch.exists_closedBall_covering_tsum_measure_le
docString: This theorem states that in a metric space equipped with the "Besicovitch property", any set `s` can be covered with a countable collection of closed balls in such a way that the sum of the measures (sizes) of these balls is at most the measure of the set `s` plus any positive real number `ε`. This is true even when we restrict the possible radii of the balls centered at a point `x` to be within a set `f x` that gets arbitrarily close to `0`. Specifically, for every point `x` in `s`, we can always find a radius within the intersection of `f x` and the open interval from `0` to any positive number `δ`, and we can then cover the set `s` with the closed balls centered at points in `t` (a subset of `s`) with these radii. The total measure of these balls will not exceed the measure of `s` plus `ε`.

L'Hôpital's rule for approaching +∞, `HasDerivAt` version

type:
∀ {l : Filter ℝ} {f f' g g' : ℝ → ℝ},
  (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atTop, HasDerivAt f (f' x) x) →
    (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atTop, HasDerivAt g (g' x) x) →
      (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atTop, g' x ≠ 0) →
        Filter.Tendsto f Filter.atTop (nhds 0) →
          Filter.Tendsto g Filter.atTop (nhds 0) →
            Filter.Tendsto (fun x => f' x / g' x) Filter.atTop l → Filter.Tendsto (fun x => f x / g x) Filter.atTop l
name: HasDerivAt.lhopital_zero_atTop
docString: L'Hôpital's rule for approaching +∞, `HasDerivAt` version

In a preconnected space, any disjoint cover by non-empty open subsets has at most one
element.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} {ι : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : PreconnectedSpace α] {s : ι → Set α},
  (∀ (i : ι), Set.Nonempty (s i)) →
    Pairwise (Disjoint on s) → (∀ (i : ι), IsOpen (s i)) → ⋃ i, s i = Set.univ → Subsingleton ι
name: subsingleton_of_disjoint_isOpen_iUnion_eq_univ
docString:
In a preconnected space, any disjoint cover by non-empty open subsets has at most one
element.

**Darboux's theorem**: the image of a convex set under `f'` is a convex set,
`HasDerivWithinAt` version.

type: ∀ {f f' : ℝ → ℝ} {s : Set ℝ}, Convex ℝ s → (∀ x ∈ s, HasDerivWithinAt f (f' x) s x) → Convex ℝ (f' '' s)
name: Convex.image_hasDerivWithinAt
docString:
**Darboux's theorem**: the image of a convex set under `f'` is a convex set,
`HasDerivWithinAt` version.

In a space with the Besicovitch property, any set `s` can be covered with balls whose measures
add up to at most `μ s + ε`, for any positive `ε`. This works even if one restricts the set of
allowed radii around a point `x` to a set `f x` which accumulates at `0`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : MetricSpace α] [inst_1 : SecondCountableTopology α] [inst_2 : MeasurableSpace α]
  [inst_3 : OpensMeasurableSpace α] [inst_4 : HasBesicovitchCovering α] (μ : MeasureTheory.Measure α)
  [inst_5 : MeasureTheory.SigmaFinite μ] [inst_6 : MeasureTheory.Measure.OuterRegular μ] {ε : ENNReal},
  ε ≠ 0 →
    ∀ (f : α → Set ℝ) (s : Set α),
      (∀ x ∈ s, ∀ δ > 0, Set.Nonempty (f x ∩ Set.Ioo 0 δ)) →
        ∃ t r,
          Set.Countable t ∧
            t ⊆ s ∧
              (∀ x ∈ t, r x ∈ f x) ∧
                s ⊆ ⋃ x ∈ t, Metric.closedBall x (r x) ∧ ∑' (x : ↑t), ↑↑μ (Metric.closedBall (↑x) (r ↑x)) ≤ ↑↑μ s + ε
name: Besicovitch.exists_closedBall_covering_tsum_measure_le
docString:
In a space with the Besicovitch property, any set `s` can be covered with balls whose measures
add up to at most `μ s + ε`, for any positive `ε`. This works even if one restricts the set of
allowed radii around a point `x` to a set `f x` which accumulates at `0`.

**Darboux's theorem**: the image of a convex set under `f'` is a convex set,
`derivWithin` version.

type: ∀ {f : ℝ → ℝ} {s : Set ℝ}, Convex ℝ s → DifferentiableOn ℝ f s → Convex ℝ (derivWithin f s '' s)
name: Convex.image_derivWithin
docString:
**Darboux's theorem**: the image of a convex set under `f'` is a convex set,
`derivWithin` version.

L'Hôpital's rule for approaching -∞, `HasDerivAt` version

type:
∀ {l : Filter ℝ} {f f' g g' : ℝ → ℝ},
  (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atBot, HasDerivAt f (f' x) x) →
    (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atBot, HasDerivAt g (g' x) x) →
      (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atBot, g' x ≠ 0) →
        Filter.Tendsto f Filter.atBot (nhds 0) →
          Filter.Tendsto g Filter.atBot (nhds 0) →
            Filter.Tendsto (fun x => f' x / g' x) Filter.atBot l → Filter.Tendsto (fun x => f x / g x) Filter.atBot l
name: HasDerivAt.lhopital_zero_atBot
docString: L'Hôpital's rule for approaching -∞, `HasDerivAt` version

An equivalence of the index set defines an equivalence between the spaces of continuous
multilinear maps. In case of normed spaces, this is a linear isometric equivalence, see
`ContinuousMultilinearMap.domDomCongrₗᵢ`.

type:
{R : Type u} →
  {ι : Type v} →
    {M₂ : Type w₂} →
      {M₃ : Type w₃} →
        [inst : Semiring R] →
          [inst_1 : AddCommMonoid M₂] →
            [inst_2 : AddCommMonoid M₃] →
              [inst_3 : Module R M₂] →
                [inst_4 : Module R M₃] →
                  [inst_5 : TopologicalSpace M₂] →
                    [inst_6 : TopologicalSpace M₃] →
                      {ι' : Type u_1} →
                        ι ≃ ι' →
                          ContinuousMultilinearMap R (fun x => M₂) M₃ ≃ ContinuousMultilinearMap R (fun x => M₂) M₃
name: ContinuousMultilinearMap.domDomCongrEquiv
docString:
An equivalence of the index set defines an equivalence between the spaces of continuous
multilinear maps. In case of normed spaces, this is a linear isometric equivalence, see
`ContinuousMultilinearMap.domDomCongrₗᵢ`.

In a preconnected space, any finite disjoint cover by non-empty closed subsets has at most one
element.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} {ι : Type u_1} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] [inst_1 : PreconnectedSpace α] {s : ι → Set α},
  (∀ (i : ι), Set.Nonempty (s i)) →
    Pairwise (Disjoint on s) → ∀ [inst_2 : Finite ι], (∀ (i : ι), IsClosed (s i)) → ⋃ i, s i = Set.univ → Subsingleton ι
name: subsingleton_of_disjoint_isClosed_iUnion_eq_univ
docString:
In a preconnected space, any finite disjoint cover by non-empty closed subsets has at most one
element.

A version of `Finset.centerMass_mem_convexHull` for when the weights are nonpositive.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} {ι : Type u_5} [inst : LinearOrderedField R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : Module R E] {s : Set E} {w : ι → R} {z : ι → E} (t : Finset ι),
  (∀ i ∈ t, w i ≤ 0) → (Finset.sum t fun i => w i) < 0 → (∀ i ∈ t, z i ∈ s) → Finset.centerMass t w z ∈ (convexHull R) s
name: Finset.centerMass_mem_convexHull_of_nonpos
docString: A version of `Finset.centerMass_mem_convexHull` for when the weights are nonpositive.

**L'Hôpital's rule** for approaching -∞, `deriv` version

type:
∀ {l : Filter ℝ} {f g : ℝ → ℝ},
  (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atBot, DifferentiableAt ℝ f x) →
    (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atBot, deriv g x ≠ 0) →
      Filter.Tendsto f Filter.atBot (nhds 0) →
        Filter.Tendsto g Filter.atBot (nhds 0) →
          Filter.Tendsto (fun x => deriv f x / deriv g x) Filter.atBot l →
            Filter.Tendsto (fun x => f x / g x) Filter.atBot l
name: deriv.lhopital_zero_atBot
docString: **L'Hôpital's rule** for approaching -∞, `deriv` version

A left adjoint preserves colimits.

See <https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/0038>.

type:
{C : Type u₁} →
  [inst : CategoryTheory.Category.{v₁, u₁} C] →
    {D : Type u₂} →
      [inst_1 : CategoryTheory.Category.{v₂, u₂} D] →
        {F : CategoryTheory.Functor C D} →
          {G : CategoryTheory.Functor D C} →
            (F ⊣ G) → CategoryTheory.Limits.PreservesColimitsOfSize.{v, u, v₁, v₂, u₁, u₂} F
name: CategoryTheory.Adjunction.leftAdjointPreservesColimits
docString:
A left adjoint preserves colimits.

See <https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/0038>.

**L'Hôpital's rule** for approaching +∞, `deriv` version

type:
∀ {l : Filter ℝ} {f g : ℝ → ℝ},
  (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atTop, DifferentiableAt ℝ f x) →
    (∀ᶠ (x : ℝ) in Filter.atTop, deriv g x ≠ 0) →
      Filter.Tendsto f Filter.atTop (nhds 0) →
        Filter.Tendsto g Filter.atTop (nhds 0) →
          Filter.Tendsto (fun x => deriv f x / deriv g x) Filter.atTop l →
            Filter.Tendsto (fun x => f x / g x) Filter.atTop l
name: deriv.lhopital_zero_atTop
docString: **L'Hôpital's rule** for approaching +∞, `deriv` version

In the characteristic zero case, the weights in the centroid sum
to 1 if the set is nonempty.

type:
∀ (k : Type u_1) [inst : DivisionRing k] {ι : Type u_4} (s : Finset ι) [inst_1 : CharZero k],
  s.Nonempty → (Finset.sum s fun i => Finset.centroidWeights k s i) = 1
name: Finset.sum_centroidWeights_eq_one_of_nonempty
docString:
In the characteristic zero case, the weights in the centroid sum
to 1 if the set is nonempty.

The intersection of an open dense set with a dense set is a dense set.

type: ∀ {X : Type u} {s t : Set X} [inst : TopologicalSpace X], Dense s → Dense t → IsOpen s → Dense (s ∩ t)
name: Dense.inter_of_isOpen_left
docString: The intersection of an open dense set with a dense set is a dense set.

Corollary of Hahn-Banach. Given a nonzero element `x` of a normed space, there exists an
element of the dual space, of norm `1`, whose value on `x` is `‖x‖`.

type:
∀ (𝕜 : Type v) [inst : IsROrC 𝕜] {E : Type u} [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E] [inst_2 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E] (x : E),
  x ≠ 0 → ∃ g, ‖g‖ = 1 ∧ g x = ↑‖x‖
name: exists_dual_vector
docString:
Corollary of Hahn-Banach. Given a nonzero element `x` of a normed space, there exists an
element of the dual space, of norm `1`, whose value on `x` is `‖x‖`.

The intersection of a dense set with an open dense set is a dense set.

type: ∀ {X : Type u} {s t : Set X} [inst : TopologicalSpace X], Dense s → Dense t → IsOpen t → Dense (s ∩ t)
name: Dense.inter_of_isOpen_right
docString: The intersection of a dense set with an open dense set is a dense set.

Center of mass of a finite collection of points with prescribed weights.
Note that we require neither `0 ≤ w i` nor `∑ w = 1`.

type:
{R : Type u_1} →
  {E : Type u_3} →
    {ι : Type u_5} →
      [inst : LinearOrderedField R] → [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E] → [inst : Module R E] → Finset ι → (ι → R) → (ι → E) → E
name: Finset.centerMass
docString:
Center of mass of a finite collection of points with prescribed weights.
Note that we require neither `0 ≤ w i` nor `∑ w = 1`.

A convex combination of two centers of mass is a center of mass as well. This version
works if two centers of mass share the set of original points.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {E : Type u_3} {ι : Type u_5} [inst : LinearOrderedField R] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : Module R E] (s : Finset ι) (w₁ w₂ : ι → R) (z : ι → E),
  (Finset.sum s fun i => w₁ i) = 1 →
    (Finset.sum s fun i => w₂ i) = 1 →
      ∀ (a b : R),
        a + b = 1 →
          a • Finset.centerMass s w₁ z + b • Finset.centerMass s w₂ z =
            Finset.centerMass s (fun i => a * w₁ i + b * w₂ i) z
name: Finset.centerMass_segment
docString:
A convex combination of two centers of mass is a center of mass as well. This version
works if two centers of mass share the set of original points.
